Name: Chld of ind/task own
Description: Farming sites are inherited by the sons or daughters of the person or the members of the task-group that owns the site

Name: Disp/bequeath by own
Description: Farming sites are disposed of, or bequeathed, in any manner chosen by the owner(s)

Name: Son-law of man owner
Description: Farming sites are inherited by son-in-law of male owner

Name: No inheritance
Description: No inheritance of house (The house may be a temporary structure, it may be disposed of at the death of the owner, or it may be occupied by the first person who claims it)

Name: Old child kin leader
Description: Houses are inherited (even if only as supervisor) by the oldest son or daughter of the recognized leader of the kinship unit (household, deme, lineage, sib) that owns the house

Name: Comp chld kin leader
Description: Houses are inherited (even if only as supervisor) by the most competent son or daughter, not necessarily the oldest, of the recognized leader of the kinship unit that owns the house

Name: Comp kin kin leader
Description: Houses are inherited (even if only as supervisor) by the most competent kin (lineal or collateral, so not necessarily a son or daughter) of the recognized leader of the kinship unit that owns the site

Name: Child of owner
Description: Houses are inherited by the son(s) or daughter(s) of the person who owns the house

Name: Retained by community
Description: House is retained by the community. (It may be dismantled, reassigned, or both)

Name: Owners choice to giv
Description: House is inherited by whomever designated by owner as heir

Name: Mans sisters son
Description: House is inherited by a man's sister's son

Name: Surviving spouse
Description: House is inherited by surviving spouse

Name: No chatt or no inher
Description: No male chattels of consequence and no inheritance of men's chattels

Name: Eq sons/some others
Description: Male chattels inherited more or less equally by all available sons, some perhaps being given to more distant collaterals, friends, or affines

Name: Predominantly sons
Description: Male chattels are predominantly inherited by sons

Name: Predomin oldest son
Description: Male chattels are predominantly inherited by the oldest son

Name: Disp/bequeath by own
Description: Male chattels are disposed of at death, or are bequeathed or sold in any manner elected by the owner before death

Name: Mans sisters son
Description: Male chattels are predominantly inherited by a man's sister's son

Name: Child w/o regard sex
Description: Male chattels are predominantly inherited by child regardless of sex

Name: Dispose/non-relative
Description: Male chattels disposed of at death, or given to nonrelatives

Name: Siblings/other members of man's matrisib
Description: Male chattels are predominantly inherited by sisters, brothers, and other members of man's matrisib

Name: No chatt or no inher
Description: No female chattels of consequence and no inheritance of women's chattels

Name: Eq daugh/some others
Description: Female chattels inherited more or less equally by all available daughters, some perhaps being given to more distant collaterals, friends, or affines

Name: Predominantly daugh
Description: Female chattels are predominantly inherited by daughters

Name: Predomin oldest daug
Description: Female chattels are predominantly inherited by the oldest daughter

Name: Disp/bequeath by own
Description: Female chattels are disposed of at death, or are bequeathed or sold in any manner elected by the owner before death

Name: Child w/o regard sex
Description: Female chattels are predominantly inherited by child regardless of sex

Name: Dispose/non-relative
Description: Female chattels disposed of at death, or given to nonrelatives

Name: Nomadic, temporary
Description: Degree of settlement of the community is that of migratory or nomadic bands occupying temporary camps for brief periods successively throughout the year

Name: Seminomad,temp/fixed
Description: That of seminomadic communities temporary camps for much of the year but aggregated in a fixed settlement at some season or seasons, e.g., recurrently occupied winter quarters

Name: Rotate,semi or perm
Description: Rotating settlements, i.e., two or more permanent or semipermanent settlements occupied successively at different seasons

Name: Semisd,some seas shf
Description: Semisedentary settlements occupied throughout the year by at least a nucleus of the community's population, but from which a substantial proportion of the population departs seasonally to occupy shifting camps, e.g., on extended hunting or fishing trips or during pastoral transhumanance

Name: Imperm,eco reasons
Description: Impermanent settlements occupied throughout the year, but periodically moved for ecological reasons, as under conditions of shifting cultivation

Name: Imperm,noneco reason
Description: Impermanent settlements occupied throughout the year, but moved from time to time for nonecological reasons, e.g., because of untoward events like an epidemic or the death of a headman

Name: Permanent
Description: Permanent settlements occupied throughout the year and for long or indefinite periods (In default of definite evidence of impermanence, raters were instructed to use7 rather than 5 or 6)

Name: Compact
Description: Settlements are compact, e.g., nucleated villages or concentrated camps

Name: Dispersed
Description: Settlements are dispersed, e.g., neighborhoods of isolated homesteads or bands whose members live in dispersed family camps

Name: Separated hamlets
Description: Settlements are composed of spatially separate hamlets or subsettlements

Name: Central and hamlets
Description: Settlements are partially dispersed, e.g., a central village or town core with outlying satellite hamlets or family homesteads

Name: Straggling
Description: Settlements are straggling, e.g. dwellings or homesteads strung out along a river bank, the seashore, or the like, in a rather continuous distribution. Such settlements merge into one another, but are considered distinct settlements by the occupants, nevertheless.

Name: Rural,no infrastrctr
Description: Within the culture being examined (focal area), the society is mostly rural; the largest communities have none of the characteristics of administrative, ceremonial, or mercantile centers

Name: Lrgst settl cer ctr
Description: The largest settlement is primarily a ceremonial or religious center for the focal area (which is perhaps a larger and more densely populated region)

Name: Lrgst settl adm ctr
Description: The largest settlement is primarily an administrative or political center for the focal area (which is perhaps a larger and more densely populated region)

Name: Lrgst settl trd ctr
Description: The largest settlement is a major mercantile or trade center for the region, whether or not it is also a ceremonial or administrative center

Name: Less 1 persn/5sq mle
Description: Less than one person per five square miles

Name: 1 prn/sq m-1 prn/5sq
Description: From one person per square mile to one per five square miles

Name: 1-5 persn per sq mle
Description: From one to five persons per square mile

Name: 5-25 pers per sq mle
Description: From five to 25 persons per square mile

Name: 25-100 persn sq mile
Description: From 25 to 100 persons per square mile

Name: 100-500 persn sq mle
Description: From 100 to 500 persons per square mile

Name: Residence
Description: There are no structures in the community that are larger or more impressive than the usual residential dwellings

Name: Impressive residence
Description: The most impressive structure (or type of structure) in the community is the residence of a category of influential persons, e.g., a mansion, palace, or large structure occupied by the local headman, a noble or a wealthy landowner

Name: Secular/public bldg
Description: The most impressive structure (or type of structure) is an assembly hall, a men's house, or other essentially secular or public building

Name: Relig/ceremony bldg
Description: The most impressive structure (or type of structure) is a temple, church, or other essentially religious or ceremonial edifice

Name: Military installatn
Description: The most impressive structure (or type of structure) is a fort, citadel, massive defensive wall, or other military installation

Name: 2+, not residence
Description: There are two or more types of impressive structures other than dwellings; no one type clearly preponderates

Name: No subdiv beyond hh
Description: There are no local subdivisions of the typical or focal community other than family households

Name: Moiety/dual division
Description: The community is divided into local moieties, i.e., into two contrasting or opposing subdivisions, or into two subdivisions that lack the characteristics of moieties

Name: Three or more divs
Description: The community is divided into three or more local subdivisions (wards, barrios, residential districts, or other)

Name: Hierarchy, 2 or more
Description: The community is organized so that, other than family households, at least two larger types of local subdivisions are present and these are hierarchical; e.g., precincts or districts exist within larger wards or parishes

Name: Voluntary
Description: Residence in particular segments of the community is determined primarily by voluntary choice

Name: Kinship
Description: Residence in particular segments of the community is determined primarily by kinship ties, as in the case of localized clans or ramages

Name: Ethnic-racial
Description: Residence in particular local segments is determined primarily by ethnic considerations, e.g., race, tribal membership, or national origins

Name: Political
Description: Residence in particular local segments is determined primarily by political factors, e.g., ideological factions, adherence to particular chiefs

Name: Religious
Description: Residence in particular local segments is determined primarily by religious affiliation, e.g., sect or cult-group membership

Name: Status
Description: Residence in particular local segments is determined primarily by status differentials, e.g., wealth, occupation, social class, or caste membership

Name: 2+ factors,no kinsh
Description: Residence in particular local segments is determined approximately equally by two or more types of consideration, among which kinship ties are relatively unimportant

Name: 2+ factors,kinship
Description: Residence in particular local segments is determined approximately equally by two or more types of consideration, among which kinship ties are relatively important

Name: No social integratn
Description: The focal or typical community is notably lacking in social integration, at least as compared with its constituent local segments or with some larger political unit of which it forms a part

Name: Ethnic/lang integrtn
Description: The focal community is distinguished from other neighboring communities by ethnic factors, e.g., by belonging to a different tribe or speaking a different language

Name: Kinship integration
Description: The focal or typical community is primarily a kinship unit, its members (or at least those of the sex that does not shift residence in marriage) belonging preponderantly to a single kinship unit, e.g., a clan or localized lineage, sib, or deme

Name: Inter kinshgrp ties
Description: The focal or typical community is integrated by multiple ties among a plurality of kinship groups, where the basic ties are kinship

Name: Social status integr
Description: The focal or typical community is integrated primarily by common social status, its members belonging preponderantly to a single social class, caste, or occupational group and differing in this respect from at least some of its neighboring communities

Name: Political ties
Description: The focal or typical community is integrated primarily (not incidentally) by common political ties, e.g., through allegiance to a particular chief, or by political and economic interdependencies, e.g., through patron-client relationships

Name: Religious ties
Description: The focal or typical community is integrated primarily by a common cult or religious affiliation not shared by neighboring communities, or by a civil-religious system of offices; in either case, the religious element transcends in importance all other types of local bonds

Name: Common residence
Description: The focal or typical community is primarily integrated, not by common kinship, social status, worship, or political allegiance, but by the choice, fact, or accident of common residence, shifts in residence from one community to another being relatively easy and frequent

Name: Monogamy
Description: Monogamy: marriage of one woman and one man

Name: Polygyny
Description: Polygyny: marriage of two or more women to one man

Name: No polygamy, or rare
Description: No polygamy, or it is rare

Name: No polygamy, or rare
Description: No polygamy, or it is rare

Name: Sororal polygyny
Description: Sororal polygyny wherein wives are sisters, or stand in roughly equivalent relationship to one another (such as classificatory sisters)

Name: Nonsororal polygyny
Description: Nonsororal polygyny wherein wives are not sisters nor do they stand in any equivalent relationship to each other

Name: General polygyny
Description: General polygyny wherein wives may be sisters or unrelated

Name: Polyandry
Description: Polyandry: marriage of several men to one woman

Name: Sororate
Description: Sororate: marriage of a man to his deceased wife's sister or "sister"

Name: Levirate
Description: Levirate: marriage of a woman to her deceased husband's brother or "brother"

Name: No 1st cousin
Description: No first-cousin marriage of any form is approved, etc.

Name: Matrilater x-cousin
Description: Matrilateral cross-cousin marriage is approved, etc

Name: Patrilat x-cousin
Description: Patrilateral cross-cousin marriage is approved, etc.

Name: Patrilater ||-cousin
Description: Patrilateral parallel-cousin marriage is approved, etc.

Name: Bilateral x-cousin
Description: Bilateral cross-cousin marriage is approved, etc.

Name: 2 & matrilat ||-cous
Description: Matrilateral cross-cousin marriage and matrilateral parallel-cousin marriage are both approved, etc.

Name: No 2nd cousin
Description: No second-cousin marriage of any form is approved, etc.

Name: Matrilater x-cousin
Description: Matrilateral cross-cousin marriage is approved, etc.

Name: Patrilat x-cousin
Description: Patrilateral cross-cousin marriage is approved, etc.

Name: Patrilater ||-cousin
Description: Patrilateral parallel-cousin marriage is approved, etc.

Name: Bilateral x-cousin
Description: Bilateral cross-cousin marriage is approved, etc.

Name: 2 & matrilat ||-cous
Description: Matrilateral cross-cousin marriage and matrilateral parallel-cousin marriage are both approved, etc.

Name: No nonlateral marriage
Description: Nonlateral marriage is not approved, etc.

Name: 2 degree nonlat marr
Description: Nonlateral marriage is approved, etc. (No marriage of any first and/or second cousins)

Name: 3 degree nonlat marr
Description: Nonlateral marriage, including cousins of third degree is approved, etc. (Rated present only if explicit statement of such. Thus, the statement "blood relatives cannot marry," without additional information on what degree of relationship constitutes "blood" relationship is rated 2)

Name: Bro-Sis exchange
Description: Brother-sister exchange (or exchange of their terminological equivalents), includes "sister-exchange" and "two men exchange sisters"

Name: Pseudo x-cousin
Description: Pseudo cross-cousin marriage (i.e., marriage to either mother's brother's or father's sister's stepchild)

Name: Agamous
Description: Marriage patterns are those of agamous communities, where there is no marked tendency or rule toward either exogamy or endogamy

Name: Exogamous
Description: Those of exogamous communities, where there is a marked tendency or rule for marriage partners to come from different communities

Name: Endogamous
Description: Those of endogamous communities, where there is a marked tendency or rule for marriage partners to come from the same community

Name: No exchange
Description: There is no exchange of gifts or services at marriage, or the exchange is negligible

Name: Equal betw br&gr fam
Description: Gift exchanges between relatives of the bride and the groom are reciprocal and roughly equal in goods, services, or both

Name: Grooms fam give most
Description: Unequal gift exchanges, which tend to approach bride-prices

Name: Brides fam give most
Description: Unequal gift exchanges, which tend to approach dowries

Name: None or little
Description: There is no exchange of gifts or services after the nuptial rite

Name: Extend 1yr/chld born
Description: Gift exchanges continue for about one year, or until the first child is born

Name: Extend 1+yr/duration
Description: Gift exchanges continue beyond approximately a year, or throughout the duration of the marriage

Name: Before marriage
Description: Bride service is performed before the marriage

Name: Up to 1yr after marr
Description: Bride service continues for up to one year after the marriage is recognized

Name: Continues 1+ years
Description: Bride service continues beyond one year

Name: No dominant type
Description: No family type clearly predominates. Several forms are present

Name: Independent/nuclear
Description: Independent families, or nuclear families composed of a man, wife, and their unmarried offspring

Name: Polygynous
Description: Polygynous families composed of a man, his wives, and their unmarried offspring

Name: Polyandrous
Description: Polyandrous families composed of a woman, her husbands, and their unmarried offspring

Name: Stem
Description: Stem families, which normally include only two related families of procreation (disregarding polygamous unions), the two being of adjacent generations

Name: Lineal
Description: Lineal families, which normally include one family of procreation in the senior generation, but include at least two such families in the next generation

Name: Extended
Description: Extended families, which normally include at least two related families of procreation in at least two adjacent generations

Name: No modal/second type
Description: No modal or secondary family form (Analysts used this attribute unless secondary form was explicitly stated or indicated)

Name: Indep polygyn fam hh
Description: Each polygynous family unit is independent with a separate house for each wife

Name: Cores polygyn fam hh
Description: Polygynous family co-resides with all wives living in same house

Name: Cores polyand fam hh
Description: Polyandrous family co-resides with all husbands living in same house

Name: Ambilocal hh
Description: Ambilocal household, where husband and wife live with (or near) the kin of one or the other, choice being based on relative need, advantage, etc.

Name: Neolocal hh
Description: Neolocal household, where husband and wife set up independent residence without respect to placement of families of orientation

Name: Virilocal hh
Description: Virilocal household, where husband and wife live with (or near) his kinsmen, but not necessarily his father

Name: Uxorilocal hh
Description: Uxorilocal household, where husband and wife live with(or near) her kinsmen, but not necessarily her mother

Name: Patrilocal hh
Description: Patrilocal household, where husband and wife live with(or near) his father

Name: Matrilocal hh
Description: Matrilocal household, where husband and wife live with(or near) her mother

Name: Avunculocal hh
Description: Avunculocal household, where husband and wife live with his mother's brother

Name: Ambilocal hh
Description: No secondary or modal, yet subordinate form

Name: Bilateral
Description: Bilateral descent, or nonunilineal descent: a person is considered equally related to kin traced through males or through females; distance, that is, number of links, rather than sex of connecting link, is used to differentiate kin

Name: Patrilineal
Description: Patrilineal descent; a person emphasizes membership within a descent line through males

Name: Matrilineal
Description: Matrilineal descent; a person emphasizes membership within a descent line through females

Name: Ego-oriented kindred
Description: No descent units beyond the ego-oriented kindred of bilateral kinsmen.  Kindreds differ for each member of the society except siblings

Name: Deme
Description: A deme is a group of people demonstrating descent from a common ancestor regardless of sex of connecting ascendants, which is united by some additional criterion(such as collective ownership, common residence, and so on). De facto, some of the recognized descendants of a given ancestor are potential members and others are actual members of the unit

Name: Matrilineage
Description: A matrilinege is a lineage in which descent is demonstrated through the female line

Name: Patrilineage
Description: A patrilinege is a lineage in which descent is demonstrated through the male line

Name: None
Description: No stipulated descent units. Kinship units are either demonstrated or nonexistent, i.e., nothing beyond the ego-oriented kindred

Name: Septs
Description: Septs are demes which are linked through presumed (stipulated) relatives

Name: Sibs
Description: Sibs are unilineal groups (matrilineal or patrilineal) that are linked through presumed (stipulated) descent

Name: None
Description: No classification of kinship units, or none beyond demes and lineages, or none beyond sibs, septs, and clans

Name: Moieties
Description: Moieties: there are only two units, or several units (bilateral or unilineal) are grouped into two divisions

Name: Phratries
Description: Phratries: any grouping of kinship units other than moiety

Name: Ambilocal
Description: Residence is ambilocal (ambilocal demes of a special types are called ramages)

Name: Dispersed 2+ commun
Description: Members of kinship unit are dispersed in several communities

Name: Localized 1 communty
Description: Members of kinship unit are localized in one community

Name: Dispersed 2+ commun
Description: Members of kinship unit are dispersed in several communities

Name: Localized 1 communty
Description: Members of kinship unit are localized in one community

Name: Egalitarian
Description: Egalitarian relations: internal statuses are differentiated solely on the basis of generation, sex, and age

Name: Ranked
Description: Ranked relations: internal statuses are differentiated on the basis of considerations other than generation or age(birth order, and so forth)

Name: Unorganized dem unit
Description: Unorganized demonstrated kinship units: no joint activity is carried out (such as ceremonies, and so forth)

Name: Organized demon unit
Description: Organized demonstrated kinship units: the unit carries out joint activities

Name: Regulate marriage
Description: Organized, but only to regulate marriage

Name: Rituals/games/feasts
Description: Organized to perform special rituals (including religious rituals, games, feasts, and so forth)

Name: Rituals &politic aff
Description: Organized to perform rituals and regulate political affairs

Name: Nonhierarchical demo
Description: Nonhierarchical: demonstrated kinship units are not differentiated with respect to prestige, power, or privilege

Name: Minimal hierarchy
Description: Minimal hierarchy: units are differentiated on the basis of prestige alone

Name: Moderate hierarchy
Description: Moderate hierarchy: units form a set, one member of which has differential power or privilege

Name: Hierarchy power/prest
Description: Hierarchical: a set of kinship units are differentiated with respect to power or privilege

Name: No corporeal property
Description: No corporeal property, moveable or not, such as hunting territory, fishing stations, houses, etc. is owned by demonstrated kinship units

Name: Movable corp prop
Description: Movable corporeal property, such as houses, boats, fish traps and weirs, etc

Name: Unmovable corp prop
Description: Unmovable corporeal property, such as fishing stations, farm land, berry patches, etc.

Name: No incorporeal prop
Description: No incorporeal property is owned by demonstrated kinship units

Name: Incorporeal property
Description: Incorporeal property includes privileges, heirlooms, rituals, songs, dances, crests, myths, names, and the like

Name: Bisexual
Description: Bisexual pattern: two terms distinguished by sex, can be glossed as "grandparent"

Name: Merging
Description: Merging pattern: a single undifferentiated term can be glossed as "grandparent"

Name: Bifurcate bisexual
Description: Bifurcate bisexual pattern: four terms, distinguished by both sex and sex of the connecting relative can be glossed as "paternal grandfather," "maternal grandfather," "paternal grandmother," and "maternal grandmother"

Name: Matriskewed
Description: Matri-skewed pattern: three terms distinguished by sex and, for females, distinguished also by the sex of the connecting relative, can be glossed as "grandfather," "paternal grandmother" (or for female, "mother's husband's brother), and "maternal grandmother" (Murdock's K)

Name: Bifurcate
Description: Bifurcate pattern: two terms distinguished by the sex of connecting relative can be glossed as "paternal grandparent" and "maternal grandparent" (Murdock's M)

Name: Ego same-sex (rare)
Description: Rare pattern distinguishing between grandparent of ego's sex, GrFa (grandfather, woman speaking) and GrMo (grandmother, man speaking) (Murdock's K; On Map Cu-152 termed "Ego same-sex distinction")

Name: Inter bif/bif-bisexM
Description: Rare pattern intermediate between bifurcate and bifurcate bisexual patterns: distinguishes between FaPa (father's parents), MoFa (mother's father), and MoMo (mother's mother (Murdock's U; On Map Cu-152 termed "Inter Bif/Bif Bisex M")

Name: Inter bif/bif-bisexF
Description: Opposite of 7: Three terms are MoPa (mother's parents), FaMo, and FaFa (Murdock's V; On Map Cu-152 termed "Inter Bif/Bif Bisex F")

Name: Three terms, dependt on who is speaking
Description: Three terms: (1) GrMo (man speaking) and GrFa (woman speaking), GrFa (man speaking), and (3) GrMo (woman speaking)

Name: Merging
Description: Merging pattern: a single undifferentiated term can be glossed as "grandchild"

Name: Bisexual
Description: Bisexual pattern: where two terms, distinguished by sex, glossed as "grandson" and "granddaughter"

Name: Self-reciprocal
Description: 3   Self-reciprocal pattern: grandparental terms, either with or without diminutive affixes, are applied to grandchildren--a grandchild being invariably called by the same term which he applies to the speaker

Name: Bifurcate-bisexual
Description: Bifurcate bisexual pattern: four terms, distinguished by both the sex of the grandchild and sex of the connecting relative can be glossed as "son's son," "son's daughter," "daughter's son," and "daughter's daughter"

Name: Bifurcate
Description: Bifurcate pattern: two terms distinguished by the sex of connecting relative can be glossed as "son's child" and â€œdaughter's child" (Murdock's M)

Name: Bifurcate-spkrs sex
Description: Bifurcate speaker's sex pattern: four terms, differentiated by the sex both of the speaker and of the connecting relative can be glossed as "son's child" (man speaking), "son's child" (woman speaking), "daughter's child" (man speaking), and "daughter's child" (woman speaking) (Murdock's N)

Name: Inter bif/bif bisex
Description: Rare pattern between bifurcate and bifurcate bisexual patterns: SoCh, DaSo, and DaDa are distinguished (Murdock's R; On Map Cu-154 termed "Inter Bif/Bif Bisexual)

Name: Int bif/bif spkr sxA
Description: Rare pattern between bifurcate and bifurcate speaker's-sex pattern: distinguishes between SoCh, DaCh woman speaking), and DaCh (man speaking) (Murdock's S; On Maps Cu-153 and Cu-154 termed "Inter Bif/Bif SpkrSex A")

Name: Maximal differences
Description: Maximal differentiation pattern for woman speaker and man speaker. Each has a set of terms for SoSo, SoDa, DaSo, DaDa (Murdock's Y)

Name: Int bif/bif spkr sxB
Description: Terms are SoCh (man speaking), SoCh (woman speaking) and DaCh (both sexes speaking) (On Maps Cu-153 and Cu-154 termed "Inter Bif/Bif SpkrSex B")

Name: Three terms, see details
Description: "Grandchild" (man speaking), "son's child" (woman speaking), "daughter's child" (woman speaking) (On Map-Cu-154 termed "Three terms")

Name: Simple bifur merging
Description: Simple bifurcate merging pattern: a single term can be glossed as "mother's brother," paternal uncles being terminologically equated with father

Name: Simple bif collaterl
Description: Simple bifurcate collateral pattern: two special terms, distinguished by the sex of the connecting relative, can be glossed as "paternal uncle" and "maternal uncle"

Name: Skewed bif collaterl
Description: Skewed bifurcate collateral pattern: three special terms, distinguished by the sex (mother or father) of the connecting person and also by age relative to that person, can be glossed as, in the case of paternal, uncles, "father's elder brother." "father's younger brother," and "mother's brother"

Name: Lineal
Description: Lineal pattern: a special single term can be glossed as "uncle," applying to both the father's and the mother's brothers and distinguishing them from the father

Name: Age-diff bif collat
Description: Age-differentiated bifurcate collateral pattern: four terms, distinguished by both relative age and the sex of the connecting person can be glossed as "father's elder brother," "father's younger brother," "mother's elder brother," and "mother's younger brother" (Murdock's K)

Name: Spkr-diff bifur merg
Description: Speaker-differentiated bifurcate merging pattern: paternal uncles are terminologically equated with father, while maternal uncles are called by two special terms, differentiated by the sex of the speaker, which can be glossed as "mother's brother" (man speaking), and "mother's brother" (woman speaking) (Murdock's M)

Name: Spkr-diff bif collat
Description: Speaker-differentiated bifurcate collateral pattern: four special terms, differentiated by the sex of the connecting person and sex of the speaker, can be glossed as "father's brother" (man speaking), "father's brotherâ€ (woman speaking), "mother's brother" (man speaking), and "mother's brother" (woman speaking) (Murdock's N)

Name: Simple bif collaterl
Description: Simple bifurcate collateral pattern: two special terms, distinguished by the sex of the connecting relative, can be glossed as "paternal aunt" and "maternal aunt"

Name: Bifurcate merging
Description: Bifurcate merging pattern: a single term can be glossed as "father's sister," maternal aunts being terminologically equated with mother

Name: Lineal
Description: Lineal pattern: a special single term can be glossed as â€œaunt," applying to both the father's and the mother's sisters and distinguishing them from the mother

Name: Generation
Description: Generation pattern: special terms are lacking for both maternal and paternal aunts, who are terminologically equated with mother

Name: Skewed bif collaterl
Description: Skewed bifurcate collateral pattern: three special terms distinguished by the sex (mother or father) of the connecting person and also by age relative to that person, can be glossed as, in the case of maternal, aunts, "mother's elder sister." "mother's younger sister," and "father's sister"

Name: Age-diff bif collat
Description: Age-differentiated bifurcate collateral pattern: four terms, distinguished by both relative age and the sex of the connecting person can be glossed as "father's elder sister," "father's younger sister," "mother's elder sister," and "mother's younger sister" (Murdock's L)

Name: Spkr-diff bif collat
Description: Speaker-differentiated bifurcate collateral pattern: three special terms, differentiated by the sex of the connecting relative and for paternal aunts also by the sex of the speaker, can be glossed as "father's sister" (man speaking), "father's sister" (woman speaking), and "mother's sister" (Murdock's M)

Name: Spkr-diff bif merge
Description: Speaker-differentiated bifurcate merging pattern: (unique to Sia Pueblo)

Name: Rare age-diff 3type
Description: Rare pattern similar to the age-differentiated bifurcate collateral pattern : FaElSi, MoElSi, and FaYoSi are distinguished, but MoYoSi is not (Murdock's U)

Name: Three terms, see details
Description: Speaker-differentiated bifurcate collateral pattern: three special terms, differentiated by the sex of the connecting relative and, for maternal aunts, also by the sex of the speaker, can be glossed as "mother's sister" (man speaking), "mother's sister" (woman speaking), and "father's sister" (converse of 7, not described by Murdock)

Name: Dravidian
Description: Dravidian pattern: four terms, distinguished by both sex and relative age of the sibling, can be glossed as "elder brother," "younger brother." and "elder sister," "younger sister" (Murdock's A)

Name: Yoruban
Description: Yoruban pattern: two terms, distinguished by age of sibling, can be glossed as "elder sibling," and "younger sibling" (Murdock's C)

Name: Algonkian
Description: Algonkian pattern: three terms, distinguished by relative age of sibling and, for elder siblings, also by sex, can be glossed as "elder brother," "elder sister," and "younger sibling" (Murdock's D)

Name: Kordofanian
Description: Kordofanian pattern: a single undifferentiated term can be glossed as "sibling" (Murdock's E)

Name: South Bantu
Description: Southern Bantu pattern: three terms, distinguished by distinguished by sex and, for siblings of the speaker's sex, also by relative age to the speaker, can be glossed as "elder sibling of the speaker's sex," "younger sibling of the speaker's sex," and "sibling of the opposite sex" (Murdock's F)

Name: East Polynesian
Description: East Polynesian pattern: four terms, distinguished by sex and, for siblings of the speaker's sex, also by relative age to the speaker, can be glossed as "elder sibling of the speaker's sex," "younger sibling of the speaker's sex," "brother" (woman speaking), and "sister"(man speaking) (Murdock's G)

Name: Quechuan
Description: Quechuuan pattern: four terms, distinguished by both sex of sibling and sex of speaker can be glossed as "brother" (man speaking), "brother" (woman speaking), "sister" (man speaking), and "sister" (woman speaking) (Murdock's H)

Name: Siouan
Description: Siouan pattern: any pattern with extensive differentiation by sex of sibling, sex of speaker, and age relative to the speaker, which results in a total of seven or eight distinct terms for siblings (Murdock's L)

Name: Caddoan
Description: Caddoan pattern: six terms, distinguished by sex of sibling, sex of speaker and, for siblings of the speaker's sex, also by age relative to the speaker, can be glossed as "elder brother" (man speaking), "younger brother" (man speaking), "brother" (woman speaking), "sister" (woman speaking), "elder sister" (woman speaking), and "younger sister" (woman speaking) (Murdock's M)

Name: Malagasy
Description: Malagasy pattern: three terms, distinguished by sex of sibling and also by sex of speaker, can be glossed as "siblings of the speaker's sex," "brother" (woman speaking), "sister" (man speaking)(Murdock's N)

Name: Jivaran
Description: Jivaran pattern: three terms, distinguished by sex of sibling and also by whichever sex is opposite that of speaker, can be glossed as "brother" (man speaking), "sister" (woman speaking), and "sibling of the opposite sex (Murdock's O)

Name: Voltaic
Description: Voltaic pattern: three terms, distinguished by sex of sibling and, for brothers, also by age relative to the speaker, can be glossed as "elder brother", "younger "brother," and "sister" (Murdock's P)

Name: Yukian
Description: Yukian pattern: three terms, distinguished by relative age and, for younger siblings, also by sex, can be glossed as "elder sibling", "younger brother," and "younger sister" (Murdock's Q)

Name: Spk-sx br/age-df sis
Description: Rare pattern: distinguished Br (man speaking), Br (woman speaking) ElSi, and YoSi (Murdock's R)

Name: Rare sex-age df+merg
Description: Rare pattern: distinguished ElBr (man speaking), ElBr (woman speaking) YoBr (man speaking), ElSi, and YoSi=YoBr (woman speaking) (Murdock's V)

Name: Rare age-sex diff
Description: Rare pattern: distinguished ElBr (man speaking), ElBr (woman speaking) YoBr, YoSi (woman speaking), ElSi (woman speaking), and Si (man speaking) (Murdock's W, appears as "Age-Difference in Map Cu-158)

Name: Age-sex diff 3terms
Description: Rare pattern: three terms can be glossed "elder sister," "younger sister," and "brother" (Extrapolated from E. B. Gifford 1922, p 18, appears as "Age-sex differences" in Map Cu-158)

Name: European
Description: European pattern: two terms, distinguished by sex, can be glossed as "brother," and "sister" (Murdock's B)

Name: Four terms
Description: Four terms: "older sibling," "younger sibling," "brother," and "sister" (appears as "Four terms in Map Cu-158)

Name: Three Terms
Description: Three terms: "brother" (man speaking), "sister" (woman speaking), and a third term meaning "brother" (woman speaking), or "sister" (man speaking) (appears as "Three terms in Map Cu-158)

Name: Age-Diff Three terms
Description: "Older sibling," "younger sibling," "sister" (man speaking), "older sister" (man speaking) (appears as "Age-Diff Three terms" in Map Cu-158)

Name: Hawaiian
Description: Hawaiian pattern: siblings, cross- and parallel cousins are called by the same term: Xc = ||c = sib

Name: Iroquois
Description: Iroquois pattern: one or more special terms for first cross-cousins differ from those for siblings, parallel cousins, and avuncular and nepotic relatives: sib = ||c =/ Xc

Name: Eskimo
Description: Eskimo pattern: one or more special terms for first cross-cousins differ from those for siblings, but do not distinguish cross from parallel cousins: Xc = ||c =/ sib

Name: Omaha
Description: Omaha pattern: the children of a mother's brother and of a father's sister (cross-cousins) are terminologically distinguished from siblings, parallel cousins, and each other but are not designated by special terms. Instead, a mother's brother's children are terminologically equated with relatives of an ascending generation, normally with the mother and her brother, and a father's sister's children are equated with relatives of an descending generation, normally with a man's sister's children and his own children

Name: Crow
Description: Crow pattern: the mirror image of the Omaha pattern, with mother's brother children terminologically equated with relatives of an descending generation, normally with a man's own children and a woman's brother's children, while a father's sister's children are equated with ascending generation, normally with father and father's sister

Name: No centralization
Description: The focal or typical community lacks centralized leadership, political authority being dispersed among its component households or other segments, which remain essentially autonomous

Name: 1 leader/inform cncl
Description: The community has a single leader or headman but lacks other political offices other than, at most, an informal council of elders

Name: 1 lead+asst-no hier
Description: The community has a single leader or headman with one or more functional assistants and/or a formal council or assembly, but lacks an elaborate or hierarchical political organization

Name: 1 lead + hierarchy
Description: The community has a single leader or headman plus an elaborate or hierarchical system of subordinate political statuses

Name: Council, no 1 leader
Description: The community lacks a single political head but is governed collectively by a committee, a council, an age-grade organization, or the like

Name: Theocratic
Description: The local political organization is theocratic, authority being vested not in secular officials but in a priesthood, a secret society, or other religious functionaries

Name: Dual|secular+religus
Description: The community has a dual system of leadership combining secular and religious offices of comparable influence and authority, e.g., headman and shaman or priest, council and secret society. (Not applicable unless the religious functionaries exercise important judicial or other political functions as well as strictly religious ones)

Name: Dual/plur lead+asst
Description: The community has dual or plural headmen with distinct but coordinate authority and one or more functional assistants, etc., but lacks a complex system of subordinate political statuses

Name: 2 sets of chiefs, dept on juris and season
Description: Two sets of village chiefs with elaborate hierarchy of political status, etc., divided jurisdiction by season

Name: No leadr/no successn
Description: No political authorities and no succession to the job

Name: Hdmn appntd by highr
Description: Succession to the office of headman, if such or an approximate equivalent exists, is through appointment (not merely acquiescence) by some higher political authority

Name: Achieved
Description: Succession is not appointive or hereditary but is achieved (by means of informal consensus or election) primarily through the acquisition of person influence, leadership qualities, prestige, or wealth

Name: Seniority/age
Description: Succession is based primarily upon seniority or age, as under gerontocracy

Name: Patri-inheritance
Description: Succession tends to be hereditary by a son or other patri-kinsmen of the preceding headman

Name: Matri-inheritance
Description: Succession tends to be hereditary by a sister's son or other matri-kinsmen of the predecessor

Name: Privilg-grp inherit
Description: Succession tends to be hereditary, not by a particular category of kinsmen but by a member of a privileged group selected for his personal qualifications by some electoral or appointive procedure
Item 6 ideally, actually tempered by 3 (qualities of personal influence, leadership qualities, prestige, or wealth)

Item 7 ideally, actually tempered by 3 (qualities of personal influence, prestige, or wealth) or by recognition of leadership qualities as determined through either informal consensus or formal elections

Name: Divination/dreams
Description: Succession based on divination, dreams, or the like

Name: Dream pwr|no inherit
Description: Nonhereditary: informally acknowledged by dream power

Name: Dream pwr, tending toward patri-inher
Description: Informally acknowledged by dream power and general qualities of leadership with tendency toward patrilineal heredity

Name: Residential kin grup
Description: Local society (or focal community) has no territorial organization larger than the residential kin group. True political organization is lacking

Name: Formal village/bands
Description: Local society is composed of several residential kin groups which are formally united into villages or bands.(Krober's and Driver's "triblet"). There is no organization larger than the village or band, which can be a seasonal (e.g., winter village or summer band) co-residence group rather than a year-round co-residence group

Name: Tribe/district
Description: Local society is composed of several residential kin groups which are formally united into villages or bands, and this political unit is further combined with others to form a tribe (several bands or several villages, the latter often being referred to as "districts"). These larger units may or may not convene in toto

Name: Residential kin grup
Description: No organization beyond the residential kin group joins together in common defense during warfare or raids

Name: Formal village/bands
Description: No organization beyond the local society--village or band, whether predominantly kin or nonkin--joins together in common defense during warfare and raids; yet extralocal groups do not customarily join together in common defense

Name: Tribe/district
Description: Local and extralocal organization (tribe or district of villages) commonly and customarily join together for common defense against warfare and raids

Name: Residential kin grup
Description: No organization beyond the residential kin group joins together to distribute food in times of scarcity

Name: Formal village/bands
Description: No organization beyond the local society--village or band--joins together to distribute food in times of scarcity (rating is applied also to villages wherein village chief had storehouse and duty to feed needy, if formal village chief was present)

Name: Tribe/district
Description: Extralocal organizations such as tribes or districts, commonly and customarily join together to distribute food in times of scarcity

Name: Residential kin grup
Description: No organization beyond the residential kin group joins together to allow access to important subsistence resources

Name: Formal village/bands
Description: No organization beyond the village or band which joins together to allow access to important subsistence resources

Name: Tribe/district
Description: Extralocal tribe or district organization commonly and customarily join together to allow access to the important subsistence resources

Name: No pol org invoked
Description: No political organization is invoked to allocate civic duties

Name: Villages/bands
Description: The village or band organization is invoked to allocate civic duties

Name: Tribe/district
Description: The tribe or district organization is invoked to allocate civic duties

Name: No alliances
Description: No alliances are formed with other groups

Name: Residentl kin groups
Description: Residential kin group form alliances with other groups from time to time

Name: Villages/bands
Description: Village or band organization is invoked to form alliances with other groups

Name: Tribe/district
Description: Tribe or district organization is invoked to form alliances with other groups

Name: No polorg/no 3d part
Description: No political organization or third-party arbitration between litigants

Name: No polorg/3d prt arb
Description: No political organization, but mediation or arbitration between litigants by third party occurs

Name: Village/band
Description: Village or band organization is invoked to punish crimes

Name: Tribe/district
Description: Tribe or district organization is invoked to punish crimes

Name: All mature males
Description: A tribal sodality that includes all mature males in the society. It excludes all others from membership

Name: All mature females
Description: A tribal sodality that includes all mature women in the society. It excludes all others from membership

Name: 1 for each sex
Description: Both male and female tribal sodalities, one for each sex

Name: 1 all mature mn&wmn
Description: A single tribal sodality that is composed of all the mature males and females in the society

Name: 1 mn&wmn + chapters
Description: A single tribal sodality that is composed of all the mature males and females in the society, but there are several different chapters of the sodality in the local community (e.g., Western Pueblo Kachina cults)

Name: 1 for men + chapters
Description: A tribal sodality that includes all mature males in the society, but there are several different chapters of the sodality in the local community

Name: Men only
Description: Restricted sodality or sodalities for men only

Name: Women only
Description: Restricted sodality or sodalities for women only

Name: Selected members
Description: Restricted sodality or sodalities for a select(sometimes self-selected) number of men and women

Name: No domin mn over wmn
Description: No dominance in numbers of sodalities or functions of sodalities by male groups over female groups

Name: Men sodality dominat
Description: Male sodalities outnumber and were more important in function than female sodalities

Name: Women sodal dominate
Description: Female sodalities outnumber and were more important in function than male sodalities

Name: Religious rituals
Description: Performed religious rituals (including rituals for fertility, weather control, etc.), dances, songs, etc.

Name: Political services
Description: Performed political services including, perhaps, defending the larger society or conducting raids for the larger society

Name: Econ services + 2,3,4
Description: Performed economic services, e.g., hunting for larger society, in addition to 2, 3, and 4

Name: Secret performances
Description: Sodality members performed all sodality functions in secret--not for public

Name: Public performances
Description: Sodality members performed all sodality functions (except initiations) in public

Name: Secret & public
Description: Some restricted sodality functions were performed in secret; some were partly public

Name: Benefit members only
Description: Restricted sodalities perform for the benefit of members only (e.g., personal dances, spirit seekings health improvement, and the like)

Name: Benefit nonmembers
Description: Restricted sodalities perform for the benefit of nonmembers in the society at large (e.g., to cure nonmembers, to insure good crops or rain, to entertain with fine dances, and so forth)

Name: Some ben mem/some non
Description: Restricted sodalities perform at times for the benefit of members and at times for the benefit of nonmembers

Name: Res sd mem/rs sd non
Description: The society has some restricted sodalities that are wholly for the benefit of members, and some that are for the benefit of members and nonmembers

Name: Club, no age classes
Description: Club(s) are present but are not divided into age-classes members only (e.g., personal dances, spirit seekings, health improvement, and the like)

Name: men clubs&womn clubs
Description: Some for men only, some for women only

Name: No duel same communy
Description: No duels between members of the same community

Name: Duel in comm, not kin
Description: Duels between members of the same community, but never or rarely between kin

Name: Duels with anyone
Description: Duels between members of the same village, band, district, or tribe, both between kin and nonkin

Name: Btwn kin grps, local
Description: Feuding is confined to kinship groups in the local community only

Name: Btwn kngrps,loc+exlo
Description: Feuding is confined to kinship groups in either the local community or the extralocal organization (tribe or district) only

Name: Btwn any kin groups
Description: Feuding occurs only among kinship groups in the local community and the extralocal organization, and between kinship groups which do not belong to the same local or extralocal organizations

Name: Btwn extralocal grps
Description: Feuding occurs among extralocal groups only

Name: Raids, not by dreams
Description: Raids, but not to fulfill visions or dream instructions

Name: Raids fulfill dreams
Description: Raids to fulfill visions or dream instructions

Name: Raids, not avenge dth
Description: Raids, but not to avenge a death

Name: Raids avenge death
Description: Raids to avenge the death of a warrior

Name: Raids, not avenge pch
Description: Raids, but not to avenge poaching

Name: Rare or never
Description: Offensive raids are either rare or never occur (0-1 per year)

Name: Moderate (2-4/yr)
Description: Offensive raids are moderate (2-4 per year)

Name: Frequent (>4per yr)
Description: Offensive raids are frequent (>4 per hear)

Name: Rare or never
Description: Rarely or never raided by another group

Name: No buffer zone
Description: No buffer zones present or mentioned in the literature

Name: Buf zone w 1 society
Description: A buffer zone is recognized with another society (a different band or village if no tribal organization, a different tribe or district if tribal organization)

Name: Buf zones >1 society
Description: Buffer zones are recognized with more than one society (different bands or villages if no tribal or district organization, different tribes or districts if tribal organization)

Name: Rare, 1 season only
Description: Warfare very rarely engaged in, but if so it was primarily restricted to one part of the year

Name: Rare, yet any season
Description: Warfare very rarely engaged in, but it occurred at any time during the year

Name: Common,1 season only
Description: Warfare commonly engaged in, but when so it was restricted to one part of the year

Name: Common, any season
Description: Warfare commonly engaged in during any time during the year

Name: Some comb of 2-8
Description: Some combination of all items 2 through 8

Name: 1+ perm mil no leadr
Description: More than one permanent military organization, but no ultimate leader

Name: 1+ perm mil w leader
Description: More than one permanent military organization with an ultimate leader (or council or leaders) with authority over all

Name: No pub cer war-raid
Description: No public ceremonies associated with warfare or raids

Name: Prepare for conflict
Description: Public ceremonies associated with preparation for conflicts only

Name: Postconflict
Description: Public ceremonies associated with postconflict period only

Name: Befor&after conflict
Description: Public ceremonies performed both before and after conflict

Name: None performed
Description: No major public ceremonies are performed

Name: 1, not regularly
Description: One major public ceremony is performed in the cultural repertoire, but not on a regular, annual basis

Name: 1+, not regularly
Description: More than one major public ceremony is performed, but not necessarily on an annual basis

Name: 1, regularly(annual)
Description: More than one major public ceremony is performed on a regular, at least annual basis

Name: 1+,regularly(annual)
Description: More than one major public ceremony is performed each year

Name: Kin grp prfm, local
Description: Where residential kin group is the largest sovereign group, ceremonies are performed for self and other kin groups from local area only

Name: Kngrp prfm,loc/exloc
Description: Where residential kin group is the largest sovereign group, ceremonies are performed not only for self and other kin groups from local area, but for people from distant areas as well--perhaps people of different dialects, languages, etc.

Name: Bnd-vil prfm, self
Description: Where band or village is the largest sovereign group, ceremonies are performed for that group only

Name: Bnd-vil prfm,slf/oth
Description: Where band or village is the largest sovereign group, ceremonies are performed for that group as well as for people from distant (other) groups

Name: Trb-dst prfm, self
Description: Where tribe or district is the largest sovereign group, ceremonies are performed for that group only

Name: Trb-dst prfm,slf/oth
Description: Where tribe or district is the largest sovereign group, ceremonies are performed for that group as well as for people from different (other) groups

Name: Both sacred&profane
Description: Major public ceremony(s) both sacred and profane

Name: Success extract/prod
Description: Public ceremonies for success at farming, fishing, hunting, or gathering (this includes replenishment of subsistence resources)

Name: Health-comm wellbeing
Description: Public ceremonies for the health and well-being of the community (this includes avenging a death)

Name: Claim status/prestge
Description: Public ceremonies to substantiate a claim to a new status, or to gain prestige, or both

Name: Ritual prescription
Description: Public ceremonies to fulfill ritual prescriptions

Name: No gifts@public cer
Description: No gifts are exchanged at public ceremonies

Name: Ml-fem prs exch@some
Description: Male-female pairs exchange gifts at some ceremonials. Most ceremonies have no gift exchange

Name: Gift exch@public cer
Description: Gifts are exchanged at public ceremonies

Name: All pool&redistribut
Description: Gifts are pooled at ceremonies by everyone who attends--locals or not--then distributed to all who attend or participate, including the local hosts

Name: Hosts to guests
Description: Gifts are given by hosts (sponsors) to those in attendance. There is no immediate exchange

Name: 4,6 &guests to hosts
Description: Gifts are exchanged at some ceremonies, given from hosts to guests at some ceremonies, and given from guests to hosts at some ceremonies

Name: Guests rec equal
Description: All guests receive, in theory, equal gifts

Name: More/better by rank
Description: Guests receive more or better gifts depending on their rank

Name: Mr/btr-distance trav
Description: Guests receive more or better gifts depending on the distance they travel to attend the ceremony

Name: Order rcv-dist travl
Description: Guests receive gifts in an order related to the distance they have traveled; the further they travel, the earlier they receive a gift during the distribution of gifts

Name: Gifts=contr to cermy
Description: Guests (or reciprocants) receive gifts consonant with their contribution to the ceremony--material or spiritual

Name: Spsr-prf by kingroup
Description: Public ceremonies sponsored and performed by kinship groups only

Name: Spsr-prf by rest sod
Description: Public ceremonies sponsored and performed by restricted sodalities only

Name: Pol ldr dir prfrmers
Description: Public ceremonies sponsored and performed under the leadership of political (or theocratic) authorities--anyone in band, village, tribe, or district can be called into service in the conduct of the ceremony

Name: Several 2, 3 and 2+3
Description: Society has several public ceremonies, some are 2, some 3, and some are both 2 and 3

Name: Several 2, several 4
Description: Society has several public ceremonies, some are 2, and some 4

Name: Several 3, several 4
Description: Society has several public ceremonies, some are 3, and some 4

Name: Some 2,some 3,some 4
Description: Society has several public ceremonies, some are 2, some3, and some 4

Name: No sps,rlg di,cm hlp
Description: Public ceremonies not sponsored in the formal sense, though directed by a ritualist or shaman with the economic help of the community (nominal sponsorship of chief or headman)

Name: Some3,some4,some3&4
Description: Society has several public ceremonies, some are 3, some 4, and some are both 3 and 4

Name: Moiety sponsor-prfrm
Description: Public ceremonies sponsored and performed by moieties under the leadership of moiety chiefs

Name: Some 2, some shaman/spir. Leader
Description: Society has several ceremonies, some are sponsored and performed by kinship groups (2), and some are sponsored nominally by shamans (or spiritual leaders)

Name: Some 2, some by ind + shaman/spir.leader + comm.
Description: The formal sponsor is any individual, the actual sponsor is a shaman, and the entire community contributes to ceremony; also, kinship groups (2) sponsor and perform such ceremonies as marrying and naming feasts

Name: Rstr loc mem slct org
Description: Private ceremonies restricted to local members of a select organization

Name: 2+slct mem other com
Description: Private ceremonies restricted to members of select organization and their counterparts in other communities

Name: Some 2, some 3
Description: Some private ceremonies restricted to local members (2), and some include counterparts in other communities (3)

Name: Outdoors, no strctre
Description: Outdoors, no structure of any kind

Name: Screened part house
Description: In a screened off part of house

Name: Special hut/enclosure
Description: In a special hut or enclosure

Name: 1 or 2
Description: Outdoors or in a house vacated by men

Name: 3 or 4
Description: In hut or in screened off part of house

Name: House, men stay
Description: In entire house, men do not leave

Name: Lying bck/recl bckwd
Description: Lying on back or reclining backwards

Name: 2 or 3
Description: Both sitting and lying on back or reclining backwards

Name: No spcl/ambiv attitd
Description: No special attitude or ambivalent attitude toward twins reported

Name: Fear/unwanted/killed
Description: Feared or not wanted or one killed

Name: 7 or # not X 3/4/5
Description: 7 or some number other than a multiple of 3, 4, or 5

Name: Flat rods/slats/bskt
Description: Flat, but made of rods, slats, or basketry materials woven together

Name: 2 and 3
Description: Both flat board(s) and flat woven types

Name: Baskets,flat&upright
Description: Upright type and flat type basketry cradles

Name: Wood/dugout/sewn box
Description: Wood container, dugout, or sewn box

Name: Trough cvrd w bckskn
Description: Deep trough frame covered with buckskin

Name: No nick/common names
Description: No nicknames or common names of address

Name: Nick-/common address
Description: Nicknames or common names of address only

Name: Nck-/comn+rit/inc nm
Description: Nicknames or common names of address, plus special names with ritual significance or incorporeal property significance

Name: Nck+special(not inc)
Description: Nicknames plus special names that were not regarded as having incorporeal property significance

Name: Spcl ritual/incrp nm
Description: Special names treated as being ritually significant or as having incorporeal property significance; very few nicknames

Name: Sib nm wmn+4 spc mn
Description: Special sib names for women, plus 4 for men

Name: Name before birth
Description: Name is bestowed on infant before birth

Name: Soon after birth
Description: Name is bestowed shortly after birth (a few days)

Name: Up to 2 years
Description: Name is bestowed during infancy (up to about 2 years)

Name: Late child/puberty
Description: Name is bestowed sometime during late childhood or puberty

Name: Thru adulthood+tknmy
Description: Names are acquired throughout adult life, and include teknonymy

Name: Not nec by relative
Description: Most important name is not necessarily bestowed by any relative

Name: Usually achieved
Description: Most important name is not necessarily bestowed by any particular kinsmen or affine, but can be achieved by a person for himself (herself) through great deeds-- economic (potlatch, for example), warfare, religious, spirit quest, and so on

Name: By parents
Description: Most important name is bestowed by parents

Name: Maternal relatives
Description: Most important name is bestowed by maternal relatives

Name: Paternal relatives
Description: Most important name is bestowed by paternal relatives

Name: 5 or 6+must achieve
Description: Most important name is bestowed by paternal or maternal relatives, but also must be achieved through great deeds--economic, warfare, religious, spirit quest, etc.

Name: 5 or 6
Description: Most important name is from maternal or paternal relatives, achievement not critical

Name: Pub cer,no feast/gft
Description: Public ceremony, but no feast or giving of gifts

Name: Pub cer&feast,no gft
Description: Public ceremony accompanied by feast but no giving of gifts

Name: Pub cer&gft,no feast
Description: Public ceremony accompanied by giving of gifts but no feast

Name: Pub cer+gifts&feast
Description: Public ceremony accompanied by both giving of gifts and feasting

Name: Pvt,kin gft to named
Description: Private ceremony in which kin offer gifts to person named only

Name: Prv,gifts to guests
Description: Private ceremony in which gifts are given to those in attendance by the parents or grandparents of the person named only

Name: Prv,gft btw gsts&fam
Description: Private ceremony in which gifts are exchanged between nuclear family of the named and those in attendance

Name: Prv w feast,no gifts
Description: Private ceremony with feast, but no gifts

Name: Priv, gifts to namer
Description: Private ceremony where gift is given to the namer(s) only

Name: Nmr gft nmd,prnt rcp
Description: Private ceremony where namer gives gift to child, child's parents might defer reciprocation or return a gift immediately

Name: 7 or# not X of 3,4,5
Description: 7 or a multiple of some number other than 3, 4, or 5

Name: 2 and 3
Description: Cold water taboo and must drink through tube

Name: 5 and 3
Description: Stale water taboo and must drink through tube

Name: 2 and 3
Description: Both hot food and fresh food taboo

Name: 3 and 4
Description: Both hot food and salt taboo

Name: 2,3,and4
Description: Fresh food, hot food, and salt taboo

Name: Lay on heated spot
Description: Lying on or near heated spot

Name: Inside sponge/wrm wtr
Description: Indoors with sponge bath and/or warm water

Name: 2 and 3
Description: Both outdoors in cold water and indoors with sponge bath and/or warm water

Name: Girl does not dance
Description: Girl does not dance at public ceremony

Name: Female frnd/rel locl
Description: Private ceremony for pubescent girl and a few close female friends and/or relations, usually from within the community

Name: Two sex frnd/rel locl
Description: Private ceremony for pubescent girl and some near kin and/or friends, both sexes, usually aged, usually from within the community

Name: Girl & proctor only
Description: Private ceremony for girl and proctor only

Name: 3 + dance + repeated
Description: Private ceremony for kin and friends, as at 3; girl and others dance; ceremony is repeated

Name: Basket/hide/mat only
Description: Only blanket, hide, or mat around corpse

Name: Pot/basket/pit remns
Description: Pot, or basket, or pit for remains of cremation

Name: Shed/canoe/box
Description: Small shed houses, canoes, or boxes

Name: Srfc/crevc/rock/cave
Description: On surface, or on slightly raised platform, or in rock crevice, rock shelter, or cave

Name: Tree/scafld/totem pl
Description: In tree or on high scaffold, or top of totem pole

Name: Tree/scaffold then 1
Description: Tree or scaffold, followed by inhumation

Name: Dying/crpse no remve
Description: No removal of dying person or corpse from house

Name: Die rmve befre death
Description: Dying person removed from house before death

Name: Crpse rmve aftr death
Description: Corpse removed from house after death

Name: Rmv bfr/immed after
Description: Remove before death if possible, otherwise immediately after death

Name: Burn house w corpse
Description: If person dies in house, house and corpse are burned

Name: Dog sacrf/gift@death
Description: Dogs and/or other (pre-European) domesticated animals killed (or freed or given away)

Name: Slav/captv sacrf@dth
Description: Slaves or captives killed (or freed, if this is prestigious)

Name: Dog&slav sac/free@dth
Description: Dogs killed or given away, and slaves killed or freed

Name: Rept mourn chief dth
Description: Only for chief or prominent man (includes memorial potlatch)

Name: Rpeat mourn all dead
Description: For all dead of the entire community

Name: Fnrl&sep mourn@persn
Description: Each deceased person has one mourning ceremony distinct from funeral

Name: Trb mourn&@prs mourn
Description: Both tribal mourning for all deceased, and one or more special mournings for each deceased person

Name: Spi qst grp rit@novc
Description: A group rite for one novice

Name: Sp qt grp rit all nv
Description: A group rite for more than one novice

Name: No spi quest sha/lay
Description: No specific spirit quest for shaman or layman

Name: Sp qst shaman only
Description: No spirit quest for layman, but quest by shaman

Name: Spi qst sha&lay same
Description: Spirit quests for shaman and layman are identical

Name: Sh/ly sp unsght/Datur
Description: Most spirits come unsought, but shamans and laymen can seek spirits or dreams in the same fashion (especially by drinking a concoction made from Jimson weed)

Name: Sha sp qst mre cmplx
Description: Spirit quests for shaman and layman are rather similar, though duration of shaman's quest is somewhat longer, and has some more specialized activities that that of layman

Name: Sha spec spi/assist
Description: Spirit quests for shaman and layman are dissimilar. Specialized spirits are sought by shaman and inheritance or sponsorship is often necessary to acquire these spirits

Name: Sha apprentc/lay not
Description: Power comes to the shaman sought or unsought; shaman must also train with another shaman; power does not come to the layman unsought. Some laymen seek special hunting abilities or the like

Name: Sha buy spirit&train
Description: Power comes through purchase and training with shaman (or medium societies); initiation to shaman or curing society is usually required as well. (Purchase is made with gifts or feasts. Moreover, sick often pledge themselves to society or cause if they are cured)

Name: Sickness+apprenticeship to shaman
Description: Power comes through sickness and cure, plus apprenticeship to shaman who cures the person

Name: Only rl spec rec pwr
Description: Only shamans, priests, ritualists, and the like receive power

Name: Sha power > lay powr
Description: Shamans possess greater power than laymen, but not a greater number of different kinds of spirits than laymen

Name: Sha>pwr+spi than lay
Description: Shaman possess greater general power than laymen, usually because he acquires a greater number of spirits, but not because the spirits have specific functions

Name: Sha pwr+spc sp > lay
Description: Shamans possess greater power as well as more specific spirits than laymen over specific functions, such as spirits to cure specific maladies

Name: Sha>spc pwr,not gnrl
Description: Shamans possess different powers than laymen, but not necessarily greater power in anything but their specialties. Shamans, for instance, cure the sick, but do not have the supernatural powers of some ritualists over other functions

Name: Some shamans > power
Description: Some shamans reported to have greater power than others

Name: Med soc > power
Description: Medicine societies reported to have greater power in concert than any particular shaman (Whole medicine society called upon to work for cure if shaman fails)

Name: Services restricted home
Description: Shamans' services called on in home community only

Name: Serve in dia/lang area
Description: Shamans' services (or some shamans' services) requested in communities other than their home communities, but within their own dialect or language group

Name: Serve beyond dia/lang
Description: Shamans' services (or some shamans' services) requested in home community, in other communities within same language, and other language-speaking communities on occasion

Name: No foreign intrustion
Description: Caused by neither foreign object nor foreign spirit

Name: Both object & spirit
Description: Both foreign object and foreign spirit

Name: No spirit/soul loss
Description: Not caused by loss of spiritual entity

Name: Soul &spirit loss
Description: Both soul loss and loss of spirit helper

Name: Soul wanders
Description: Loss by wandering of soul, usually on own volition

Name: Loss by theft
Description: Loss by theft, usually by a ghost or some other supernatural agent (not a sorcerer, or witch, or bad medicine man)

Name: Loss by rule violation
Description: Loss by violation of an interdiction

Name: Supernatural sources
Description: Intrusions caused by supernatural sources only, no human agents involved

Name: Shaman/sorcerer/witch
Description: Intrusions caused by bad shamans, sorcerers, etc.

Name: Supernatural & human agents
Description: Intrusions caused both by supernatural agents and sorcerers, etc.

Name: Shaman/sorcerer/witch
Description: Souls stolen by shamans, or sorcerers, or witches

Name: White magic
Description: White imitative magic, such as shooting with arrows or poison darts. wooing through entreating, coaxing, or gesturing, or stabbing an animal effigy, or simulating crop growth, and so forth, is practiced

Name: Black magic
Description: Black imitative magic used to harm humans

Name: Specialists perform
Description: Only specially qualified people such as shamans or evil shamans (witches, sorcerers) could perform imitative magic

Name: No contagious/formulaic
Description: No white contagious or formulaic magic

Name: White magic
Description: White contagious or formulaic magic used for good purposes

Name: No contagious/formulaic
Description: No black contagious or formulaic magic

Name: Black magic
Description: Black contagious or formulaic magic used to harm humans

Name: No contagious/formulaic
Description: No one performs contagious or formulaic magic

Name: Anyone could perform
Description: Anyone could perform contagious or formulaic magic

Name: Specialists perform
Description: Only specially qualified people such as shamans or evil shamans (sorcerers) could perform contagious or formulaic magic

Name: No magic/charms
Description: No gambling magic techniques or charms

Name: Magic technices
Description: Gambling magic techniques but not charms

Name: Charms
Description: Gambling charms but not magic techniques

Name: Magic and charms
Description: Both gambling magic techniques and charms

Name: No magic/charms
Description: No love magic techniques or charms

Name: Magic technices
Description: Love magic techniques but not charms

Name: Charms
Description: Love charms but not magic techniques

Name: Magic and charms
Description: Both love magic techniques and charms

Name: No in-law avoidance or missing data
Description: No in-law avoidance or missing data
